Home / About the Global Compact / Biographies of Global Compact Board Members

Biographies of Global Compact Board Members

Business

Mr. Toshio Arima
Director and Executive Advisor to the Board, Fuji Xerox, Japan

Mr. Arima joined Fuji Xerox in 1967. In 1992 he became the company's Director, and in 1996 its Managing Director. That same year Mr. Arima was appointed President and CEO of Xerox International Partners, based in California, United States. In 2002 he became President of Fuji Xerox. Mr. Arima has held his current position as Executive Advisor to the Board since 2007. He became the Chair of the Board of the Global Compact Japan Network (GC-JN) in April, 2008 when GC-JN reorganized to become a CEO-lead organization. He is also actively promotes productive and environmentally-friendly work style as a Chairman of the Japan Telework Association. He graduated from International Christian University College of Liberal Arts in Japan.

Mr. Guillermo Carey
Senior Partner, Carey & Allende Abogados, Chile

Mr. Carey is Senior Partner at Carey & Allende, a leading law firm in Chile. He has extensive international experience in the energy, petrochemical, pulp and paper, and aviation sectors. He participated in solving various conflicts through mediation or out-of-court agreements and was involved in resolving several conflicts with Mapuche communities. Mr. Carey is actively involved in issues of social responsibility and pro bono work. He is one of the Members of the Center of Mediation and Arbitration Arbitral Committee of the Chamber of Commerce of Santiago (CAM) and a former Professor of Private International Law at the Catholic University.

Mr. Tae-Won Chey
President & Chairman, SK Group, Republic of Korea

Mr. Chey was appointed Chairman of the Board and CEO of SK Group in 1998. He is a member of the World Economic Forum (WEF) and the Boao Forum. He was named as one of the “Global Leaders for Tomorrow” at the WEF in Davos, Switzerland in 1999. He also served as Co-Chair of the East Asia Economic Summit 2002 in Malaysia, the Asian regional forum of WEF. He also taught a Techno Economics and Policy Program at Seoul National University. Mr. Chey holds a Bachelor of Arts degree in Physics from Korea University and completed a Ph.D. program in Economics at the University of Chicago.

Ms. Ying Chen
Director, Beijing Rong Zhi Institute of Corporate Social Responsibility, China

Ms. Ying is the Director of Beijing Rong Zhi Institute of Corporate Social Responsibility, and the director of the Center Office of the Global Compact Network China. She launched the China Business Council for Sustainable Development (CBCSD) in 2002 and became the council’s permanent director. As a professional from China in Corporate Social Responsibility Work Force of International Organization for Standardization (ISO), she participated in the establishment of the International Standard giving guidance on Social Responsibility (ISO26000) in 2004. Mrs. Ying is actively involved in promoting social responsibility issues in China. She has been working on a draft of Guideline Opinions for Central Enterprises Promoting Social Responsibility to be issued by State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council. She is a graduate of Hangzhou University.

Mr. Fernando Chico Pardo
President of Grupo Aeroportuario del Sureste (ASUR), Mexico

Mr. Chico successfully led in 2003 the privatization effort of Grupo Aeroportuario del Sureste, which operates 9 airports in southeastern Mexico. He is the majority shareholder, and President of the Board of Directors; ASUR is a publicly traded company in the Mexican and New York stock exchanges with market capital of over 2 billion dollars. He has been a member of the Investments Committee of the United Nations Joint Staff Pension Fund for more than a decade, and board member of several Latin American companies including Grupo Financiero Inbursa, Grupo CARSO, Grupo Posadas, and Quantum Group of Funds. He co-founded and was the President of Grupo Financiero Inbursa, one of the leading financial institutions in Mexico. Additionally he presides over Promecap, a private equity investment firm dedicated to Mexican projects as well as the Board of Trustees for Universidad Iberoamericana, one of the nation’s top three higher education institutions. He actively participates as a benefactor, and mainly as a leader, in several non-profit organizations that embrace diverse aspects of Mexico, including press, childhood issues, social and environmental development. Mr. Chico received his MBA from Kellogg at Northwestern University.

Mr. Juan de la Mota
President, Global Compact Spanish Network

Prior to becoming President of the Global Compact Spanish Network, Mr. de la Mota worked as Managing Director of Standard & Poor’s (S&P) Spain. From 1992 to 2008, he was President and CEO of S&P Spain SA, and a member of S&P European Leadership Team and of the McGraw-Hill Companies Global Leadership Team. He is a current member of the Institute of Corporate Directors (Instituto de Consejeros-Administradores) and a trustee of Fundación Lealtad. He was the founding manager of Compañía Española de Financiación del Desarrollo SA, a development financial institution in Spain, and served as Board Director of Compañía Española de Crédito y Caución SA and Empresa Nacional del Uranio SA.  From 1976 to 1989, Mr. de la Mota held several positions at the Ministry of Finance and Trade in Madrid, and also as Counsellor (Economy and Trade) at the Embassy of Spain in Ottawa, Canada. He was also professor of economics and external trade at the Complutense University of Madrid.  Mr. de la Mota graduated in Business and Economics at the Complutense University of Madrid. He holds a graduate degree in Business Administration from the University of Ottawa, and has attended several Executive Programs in Businesses, from INSEAD in Fontainbleau as well as the Executive Development Program from Darden Graduate School of Business Administration at the University of Virginia, U.S.

Mr. José Sergio Gabrielli de Azevedo
President and Chief Executive Officer, Petrobras, Brazil

Mr. Gabrielli has been CEO of Petrobras since 2005 and also serves as President of the Executive Board of Petrobras Transporte S.A., Petrobras Química S.A., and Petrobras Gás S.A. Prior to this role he held the posts of Financial Director and Director of Investor Relations at Petrobras. During Mr. Gabrielli’s tenure, Petrobras received several awards, including the Transparency Trophy, the Best Investor Relations for an Individual Investor Award, and Respect for the Individual Investor Prize. Mr. Gabrielli is a full-time professor on leave at the Federal University of Bahia (Universidade Federal da Bahia). He has published several articles and books on productive restructuring, the labor market, macroeconomics, and regional development. Mr. Gabrielli holds a Ph.D. in Economics from Boston University and Master’s and Bachelor’s degrees from the Federal University of Bahia.

Mr. Charles O. Holliday
Chairman of the Board, DuPont, US

Mr. Holliday became Chairman of the Board of DuPont in January, 1999. He retired from DuPont as CEO in January, 2009 after serving in this post for nearly 11 years.  Mr. Holliday currently serves on the Board of Directors of Deere & Co., CH2M HILL, and ClimateWorks Foundation. He is Chair Emeritus of the Board of Catalyst and Chairman of the U.S. Council on Competitiveness. He is former chairman of the Business Roundtable's Task Force for Environment, Technology and Economy, the World Business Council for Sustainable Development, the Business Council, and the Society of Chemical Industry America. Mr. Holliday is a member of the National Academy of Engineering and a founding member of the International Business Council. He co-authored Walking the Talk, a book which details the business case for sustainable development and corporate responsibility.

Mr. Jamshed Irani
Director of the Board, Tata Group, India

Mr. Irani retired as Managing Director of Tata Steel in 2001 after holding this post for almost a decade. He is currently Director of the Board of Tata Steel as well as Tata Sons, Tata motors, Tata Teleservices, BOC India, Electrosteel Castings, and Repro India. He also serves as Chairman of Tata Refractories, TRF, and Kansai Nerolac Paints. He is Chairman of the Society and Board of Governors of the Indian Institute of Management in Lucknow and a member of Global Advisory Board of the Asian Center for Corporate Governance and Sustainability. In 1997 Queen Elizabeth II conferred on Dr. Irani honorary Knighthood (KBE) for his contributions to Indo-British Trade and Cooperation. In 2007 he was honored by the President of India with the award “Padma Bhushan” for his services to trade and industry in the country.

Ms. Anne Lauvergeon
Chair of the Executive Board, Areva, France

Ms. Lauvergeon has been Chair and CEO of AREVA NC group since June 1999 and CEO of AREVA group since July 2001. She began her professional career in the iron and steel industry and afterward moved to Usinor. In 1984 she directed European safety studies in the chemical industry for the Commissariat à l' Energie Atomique. From 1985 to 1988, she supervised utility underground activities in the Paris region. Ms. Lauvergeon was appointed Deputy Director of the General Mining Council in 1988. In 1990, she joined the staff of the President of France as Advisor for Economic International Affairs. In 1991 she became Deputy Chief of Staff in the French Presidency and acted as 'Sherpa' to the President, in charge of the preparation of G7 summits. In 1995, she became a partner of Lazard Frères & Cie in Paris, following several months spent in the company's New York office. In March 1997, she was appointed Senior Executive Vice President of Alcatel Telecom. In July 1998 she became a member of the Executive Committee of the Alcatel Group, in charge of the group's international organization and overseeing the group's interests in the energy and nuclear field. Ms. Lauvergeon is a graduate of the Ecole des Mines and of the Ecole Normale Supérieure, holding a degree in physics.

Ms. Ntombifuthi Mtoba
Chair of the Board, Deloitte, South Africa

Ms. Mtoba is the first black African woman appointed as a partner, then Board member, and Chair of the Board by one of the “Big Four” accounting firms in South Africa.  She is a member of the NEPAD Business Foundation; she serves on the Board of the Public Investment Corporation, South African Reserve Bank Standing Committee for the revision of the Bank’s Act and Chairman of the Council of the University of Pretoria. Ms. Mtoba was also the first woman national president of the Association for the Advancement of Black Accountants in Southern Africa (ABASA). Ms. Mtoba is the 2004 winner of Businesswoman of the Year and in November 2005 she won the Organization of Women in International Trade (OWIT) USA International Woman of the Year Award, making her the first woman from the African continent to receive this accolade.

Mr. Mads Øvlisen
Chair, Lego, Denmark

Mr. Øvlisen has been Chairman of the Board of Directors of Lego since 1996, after becoming a Board member in 1990. He is also Chairman of the Danish Arts Council and a member of the Board of Directors of the Wanas Foundation, Sweden. Mr. Øvlisen is adjunct professor of corporate social responsibility at the Copenhagen Business School. In the past, he served as Chairman of the Copenhagen Center for Social Responsibility and was a founding Co-Chair of the European Academy for Business in Society. Mr. Øvlisen served as president and CEO of Novo Industri in 1981-1989 and Novo Nordisk in 1989-2000. He is a former board member of the Novo Foundation and of the Novo Nordisk Foundation.

International Labor and Business Organizations

Mr. Antonio Peñalosa
Secretary-General, International Organization of Employers

Mr. Peñalosa has held the post of Secretary-General of the International Organization of Employers (IOE) since 1999. He began his career at the IOE in 1978 as Assistant to the Director-General. Currently he is responsible for the management and relations of the Organization with its members, other interested groups and public organizations. As a spokesperson for UN agencies, he acts as Secretary and Coordinator of the Employers’ Group within the International Labor Organization (ILO), particularly the Governing Body and the International Labor Conference. Antonio Peñalosa is also a member of the International Organization for Migration (IOM) Business Advisory Board.

Mr. Guy Ryder
General Secretary, International Trade Union Confederation

Mr. Ryder is the General Secretary of the International Trade Union Confederation (ITUC), the world’s largest trade union body with a membership of 170 million workers in 157 countries. In his capacity as General Secretary of the ITUC, Mr. Ryder represents the interests of workers to international organizations including the United Nations and the tripartite International Labor Organization (ILO). Mr. Ryder was elected General Secretary of the ITUC at its founding Congress in 2006 after having served in the same capacity in the ITUC’s predecessor organization the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions (ICFTU) since 2002. Prior to that, Mr. Ryder worked successively at the Trades Union Congress (TUC) of Great Britain and at the International Federation of Commercial, Clerical, Professional and Technical Employees, as Director of the Geneva Office of the ICFTU and Secretary of the Workers’ Group of the Governing Body of the ILO, as Director of the Bureau for Workers’ Activities of the ILO, and as Director of the Office of the Director-General of the ILO. Mr. Ryder is a graduate of Cambridge University. 

Mr. Jean Rozwadowski
Secretary General, International Chamber of Commerce

Mr. Rozwadowski became the Secretary General of the International Chamber of Commerce on 1 July 2009. As chief executive of the world business organization, he oversees an array of activities designed to help companies deal with the challenges of globalization and represent the interests of world business to governments and intergovernmental organizations. Mr. Rozwadowski was President of the Latin American and Caribbean Division of MasterCard between 1999 and 2004. Previously he was the company’s Executive Vice President for Europe, the Middle East and Africa, based in Belgium. Prior to joining MasterCard Mr. Rozwadowski held numerous executive positions during a 20-year career with American Express, heading up the Southeast Asia and Middle East divisions, based in Singapore and Bahrain, respectively, and leading American Express operations in Brazil for six years. Mr. Rozwadowski also served as President of the American Chamber of Commerce in Sao Paulo, Brazil. He graduated with an MBA from the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College in Hanover, New Hampshire and earned his undergraduate degree from the École Supérieure de Commerce de Paris.

Mr. Manfred Warda
General Secretary, International Federation of Chemical, Energy, Mine and General Workers’ Unions

Mr. Warda was elected as General Secretary by the congress of the International Federation of Chemical, Energy, Mine and General Workers’ Union (ICEM) in 2007. Prior to the appointment, Mr. Warda served as Head of the International Department of the German trade union IGBCE. He began his career at Industriegewerkschaft Bergbau und Energie (IGBE), the German Mineworkers’ Union, in 1977 after working for the German petrol sales company ARAL AG . After serving as an assistant and then Head of the President's Office, Mr. Warda became Head of IGBE's International Department in 1990. Following the 1997 merger that created IGBCE, he continued as Head of the IGBCE’s International Department. Mr. Warda has served as a board member of different companies in Germany and the United States for many years. Mr. Warda a graduate of Bochum University, Germany.

Civil Society

Ms. Habiba Al Marashi
Chair, Emirates Environmental Group

Ms. Al Marashi is the co-founder and Chairperson of Emirates Environmental Group, a pioneering non-government organisation based in Dubai in the United Arab Emirates. Mrs. Al Marashi is a UAE national who began her professional career working with the Federation of the UAE’s Chambers of Commerce & Industry and Dubai Development Board, Government of Dubai.  Ms. Al Marashi played a key role in the growth of the EEG, which is the only active, multi-sector organization in the UAE that has successfully brought the government, private sector and community under the same banner. Through her leadership, she initiated the first corporate social responsibility (CSR) network in the country in 2004 with local and multinational companies. She has been a board member of the UN Global Compact since 2006 and President of the UN Global Compact GCC States Local Network.  Under Ms. Al Marashi’s guidance, EEG became the first environmental NGO in the world to receive an ISO 14001 certification. EEG is also the only civil society organization in the GCC, with accreditation with two highly esteemed UN bodies, namely the United Nations Convention to Combating Desertification (UNCCD) and the United Nations Environmental Program’s (UNEP) Governing Council. EEG also signed a Memorandum of Understanding and Cooperation with United Nations Development Programme and the Prince of Wales International Business Leaders Forum to name a few. In 2008, EEG was formally accredited by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN). These accreditations ensure the Group’s involvement and participation in international environmental discussions, programs and campaigns. Apart from this she is one of the Founding Members of the Emirates Green Building Council (EmiratesGBC). Ms. Al Marashi is involved in many leading initiatives on environment, women and development at the national, regional and international levels. She is a member of the Global Women’s Consultative Council, and a recognized representative and spokesperson for West Asian Arab nations at high ranking international summits. She was short-listed for the Dubai Government Excellence Awards in 2000. Ms. Al Marashi was given the Emirates Business Women Award for year 2002 –2003 in the Professional Category.

Mr. Oded Grajew
Chair of the Board, Instituto Ethos de Empresas e Responsabilidade Social

Mr. Grajew is the founder and Chair of the Board of Instituto Ethos de Empresas e Responsabilidade Social (Ethos Institute of Business and Social Responsibility) as well as the founder and former President/Chairman of the Board of the Abrinq Foundation for Children and Adolescents’ Rights. Mr. Gajew is the originator of Movimento Nossa São Paulo (Our São Paulo Movement) in Brazil, as well as the founder/partner of Todos pela Educação (All for Education). He is former Chairman of the Board of Instituto Ethos and UniEthos - Education for Social Responsibility and Sustainable Development. Present member of the Board of the Council of Economic and Social Development of the Brazilian Government, as well as former advisor to the President of Brazil. Mr. Grajew is a member of the Board of the Akatu Institute for Conscious Consumption. He is the originator of the World Social Forum, as well as the founder-member of Pensamento Nacional das Bases Empresariais (Thoughts of the National Business Community), and the Founder and present Coordinator of Cives - Brazilian Association of Businessmen for Citizenship.

Ms. Huguette Labelle
Chair, Transparency International

Ms. Labelle is Chair of the Board of Transparency International, Chancellor of the University of Ottawa, Vice-President of the Council of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature, Chair of the Board of the Centre for the Financial Services OmbudsNetwork and of the E7 Scholarship Selection Committee. She is Co-Chair of the Task Force on China’s Environment and Development Review and Prospect. Dr. Labelle has held several government posts in Canada, including President of the Canadian International Development Agency from 1993 to 1999, deputy head of the Millennium Bureau of Canada in 1998, deputy minister of Transport Canada from 1990 to 1993, chairman of the Public Service Commission of Canada from 1985 to 1990, associate secretary to the cabinet and deputy clerk of the Privy Council in 1985, and under-secretary of state in the department of the secretary of state from 1980 to 1985.

Ms. Mary Robinson
Chair, Realizing Rights: The Ethical Globalization Initiative

Ms. Robinson is the first female President of Ireland (1990-1997) and former United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (1997-2002). Ms. Robinson is a member of the Elders, Co-founder and former Chair of the Council of Women World Leaders and Vice President of the Club of Madrid. She is Chair of the GAVI Alliance Board. She chairs the Fund for Global Human Rights and is Honorary President of Oxfam International, and Patron of the International Community of Women Living with AIDS (ICW). She is President of the International Commission of Jurists. Ms. Robinson serves on the board of the Mo Ibrahim Foundation, is a member of the Royal Irish Academy and the American Philosophical Society and chairs the Irish Chamber Orchestra. She was educated at the Trinity College of the University of Dublin, King’s Inns Dublin and Harvard Law School.

Ex-Officio

Mr. Georg Kell
Executive Director, UN Global Compact Office

Georg Kell is the Executive Director of the United Nations Global Compact, the world’s largest voluntary corporate responsibility initiative with more than 6,000 participants in over 130 countries. Spanning more than two decades, his career with the United Nations began in 1987 at the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) in Geneva. In 1997, Mr. Kell joined the Office of the UN Secretary-General in New York, where he spearheaded the development of new strategies to enhance private sector engagement with the work of the United Nations. As one of the Global Compact’s key architects, he has led the initiative since its launch in 2000, building the most widely recognized global business platform on human rights, labor, environment, and anti-corruption. Prior to joining the UN System, Mr. Kell worked as a researcher at the Fraunhofer Institute in Germany and as a financial analyst evaluating multinational companies’ investment portfolios in Asia and Africa. A native of Germany, he holds advanced degrees in economics and engineering from the Technical University of Berlin

Sir Mark Moody-Stuart
Chairman, Foundation for the Global Compact

Sir Mark is Chairman of the Global Compact Foundation. He is a Director of HSBC Holdings PLC, Accenture Ltd, and Saudi Aramco. He was Chairman of Anglo American plc, a global mining company from 2002 to2009. He was Chairman of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies from 1998 to 2001, having worked for Shell since 1966. In 2000 and 2001, he Co-Chaired the G-8 Task Force on Renewable Energy and also Chaired Business Action for Sustainable Development, a joint initiative of the International Chamber of Commerce and the World Business Council for Sustainable Development in the run up to the World Summit on Sustainable Development in Johannesburg, 2002. He was also on the board of the Global Reporting Initiative from 2002 to 2007. Sir Mark became a Knight Commander of the Order of St. Michael and St George in June 2000.
